snippet: A study found that unpaid traffic fines for minor infractions often resulted in license suspensions that kept poor and working-class people from paying their debt.
abstract: Study prepared by the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights of the San Francisco Bay Area finds that local traffic courts are frequently suspending licenses of those unable to pay fines for minor infractions; also finds that such suspensions have disproportionate impact on poor and working-class people, often preventing them from paying original debt, in many cases because suspension cost them their job.
lead_paragraph: A study found that unpaid traffic fines for minor infractions often resulted in license suspensions that kept poor and working-class people from paying their debt.

headline.main: Economic Disparity Is Seen in California Driver’s License Suspensions
headline.print_headline: Study Finds Economic Disparity in Driver’s License Suspensions in California
